Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Systems Approach to Study Horizontal Acquisition of Regulatory DNA

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Description
Horizontal gene transfer is the process by which genes are disseminated between different microbes in nature. This process is central to the ability of microbes to rapidly evolve new traits and has been linked to the spread of drug resistance and pathogenesis in humans, livestock, and agriculture. However, basic determinants that govern how genes spread in natural environments are not well characterized. This work utilizes a systems and synthetic biology approach to experimentally probe the underlying rules that determine the horizontal dissemination of genes between diverse bacteria species. A foundational idea is that gene regulation is an important driver in gene transfer. Results from this work will shed new light on a fundamental property of microbial evolution and address critical knowledge gaps for understanding the propagation of genetic material in natural and man-made environments. This endeavor will also lead to the characterization of genetic parts that will be useful for engineering a variety of microbes relevant in areas of biotechnology, biomaterials, and biofuels. These new insights can lead to improved strategies to contain the spread of problematic genetic materials that may lead to diseases in humans, livestock and crops, as well as those that alter the natural ecosystem in undesirable ways. This research will also provide creative educational and training opportunities for students from high school and regional undergraduate institutions with a diverse student population.

Technical Description
Recent sequencing efforts have highlighted the significance of horizontal gene transfer (HGT) in shaping microbial evolution. However, systems-level principles that govern the transfer and assimilation of foreign DNA into new hosts remain largely unexplored. An important corollary is that foreign regulatory elements that determine the level of transcription and translation for downstream protein-coding sequences may play a key role in HGT. Poorly expressed or translated foreign genes will not be beneficial to the receiving microbe and will be lost, while deregulated genes with abnormally high levels of expression are also selected against as they cause unnecessary resource burdens on the host. Therefore, the "Goldilocks" window of regulatory compatibility between donor and recipient microbes may be a significant and thus far underappreciated determinant in HGT. This NSF CAREER project aims to develop a systems and synthetic biology research program to answer key questions in this area. The proposal aims to determine whether compatibility of cis-regulatory elements in the donor DNA and the recipient's regulatory machinery is a key determinant of HGT and genomic acquisition of new DNA. This proposal aims to develop high-throughput methods using DNA library synthesis and sequencing to measure transcriptional and translational activity of tens of thousands of horizontally acquired regulatory elements. This proposal also aims to understand the regulatory barriers of HGT in diverse bacterial systems and identify strategies by which promiscuous mobile DNA such as conjugative plasmids and transposons are able to overcome such barriers to function in different species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project is to develop a series of high-throughput methodologies to study mobile DNA that transfer between bacteria. More specifically, the project focuses on regulatory elements (i.e., promoters, ribosomal binding sites) that govern gene expression of mobile DNA. This work has important implications for our understanding of how such genetic materials can transmit, persist, and evolve in different microbial hosts, which has relevance for curbing the spread of antibiotic resistance and pathogenicity in microbial communities.

Toward this goal, we pioneered several new approaches that leverage metagenomic mining from sequenced genomes, high-throughput DNA synthesis from oligonucleotide microarrays, and next-generation sequencing to enable large-scale characterizations of the activity of regulatory elements in diverse bacteria. We discovered important rules that dictate the activity of specific regulatory elements based on their native sequence motifs as well as features of the bacterial host such as genomic GC content. This work greatly expanded the toolbox of well-characterized regulatory elements that can be used by synthetic biologists to build new genetic circuits in different bacteria. Furthermore, we devised a framework for designing species-selective genetic programs that leverage the differential activity of these regulatory elements in different bacteria, thus enabling tunability of its activation in across a diverse microbial community.We also develop general platforms for horizontal gene transfer of DNA between bacteria including in complex microbial community such as a gut microbiome, as well as methods to record in real-time horizontal gene transfer events using CRISPR-Cas spacer acquisition systems. Moreover, new genetic tools associated with programmable transcriptional activation and programmable RNA-guided DNA integration using CRISPR-Cas systems have been developed under this project. Together, this work has yielded over a dozen publications in high impact journals (i.e., Nature Methods, Nature Biotechnology, Nature Chemical Biology, Nature Communications, Molecular Systems Biology) and patent applications as well as generated biological resources and characterization datasets that are broadly useful for the synthetic biology and systems biology community. A number of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows have been trained under this project.

With regard to the broader scientific outreach activities, the project facilitated the initiation of a perennial iGEM program at Columbia University to foster undergraduate education and participation in synthetic biology curriculum and research. Over two dozen undergraduates at Columbia university were trained throughout the effort. A student-led group, the Synthetic Biology Initiative, was founded at Columbia as a direct result of these activities. Furthermore, students supported through our program developed workshops for underserved communities in New York City on STEM topics including synthetic biology and bioengineering, in collaboration with local science education outreach organizations ThinkSTEAM and BioBUS. Finally, we were able to give several seminars at Genspace and Biotech without Borders, local non-profit DIY Bio organizations, and engage with local community member in Brooklyn, NY to discuss topics around synthetic biology, microbiome research, and biosecurity and biosafety associated with expanded capabilities in the era of bioengineering advances.
